ENST Course code of conduct1.Share responsibility for including all voices in the conversation. 2.Listen respectfully.3.Be open to changing your perspectives based on what you learn from others.4.Understand that we are bound to make mistakes in this space.5.Understand that your words have effects on others.6.Take pair work or small group work seriously.7.Understand that others will come to these discussions with different experiences from yours.8.Make an effortto get to know other students. Introduce yourself to your peers during group discussion and class activities.9.Understand that there are different approaches to solving problems.From page 6 of the course syllabus. What will we study in ENST 100•Environment:•Natural world of plants, animals, bacteria, protists, and fungus•Physical characteristics, such as soils, air, water, climate•Nutrient cycling and the flow of energy•How life is sustained•Society:•The social institutions, culture, science and technology, worldviews, behaviors,  etc. that influence and are influenced by the environment.Society

What is Environmental Studies?•Mission oriented: Tries to understand the causes of environmental problems and offer solutions that help people and the earth.•Systems oriented: Recognizes that environmental problems result from complex, interrelated issues.•Interdisciplinary:Draws on many fields of science, i.e., biology, chemistry, economics, psychology, political science, etc.
https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-surprise-rescue-of-jamaica-coral-reefs-shows-nature-can-heal-3/

Major Themes in Environmental Studies•Environmental justice and equity•Environmental quality (including air and water pollution, climate change)•Human population and well-being•Sustainable use of resources•Land use, habitat loss, & biodiversity•Ecosystem services•Environmental values and valuinghttps://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/?menu=1300

Course Learning Objectives1.Gain knowledge of the physical, chemical, and biological aspects of the environment.2.Understand issues facing the environment from a scientific and social perspective.3.Explore how environmental issues affect humans, from multiple perspectives.4.Discuss solutions to environmental degradation through law, policy & markets, technology, and human behavior*.5.Learning objectives in this course are aligned with those of the Environmental Studies Program: https://dornsife.usc.edu/environmental-studies/learning-objectives/
*Both individual behavior and collective action

A word about participation
As a record of active participation and attendance, you will be asked to complete and submit ‘mini’ in-class activities individually or in teams, e.g., collect some data, watch and reflect on a video or newspaper story, calculate your environmental footprint, participate in discussion, write a minute-paper, etc. 
These activities will help to illustrate key course concepts and provide a basis for in-class discussion.  Some activities will help me (and you) to gauge your understanding of the topics as we progress through the course, andallow me to provide feedback. 
In-class and outside-of-class work may be assigned at any point before or during the class.  This will be announced in class and on BB.

Plagiarism: DefinitionPresenting someone else’s ideas as your own, either verbatim or recast in your own words –is a serious academic offense with serious consequences. Please familiarize yourself with the discussion of plagiarism in SCampus in Part B, Section 11, “Behavior Violating University Standards” https://policy.usc.edu/scampus-part-b/(scroll down to find Section 11). Any submitted work with evidence of plagiarism or other forms of academic misconduct, whether by accident or on purpose, will receive a grade of zero (0). Cases of academic misconduct may also be referred for further review and disciplinary action.

What does plagiarism look like?Paragraph example from a student’s assignment: •Dioxins are a group of toxic chemical compounds that share certain chemical structures and biological characteristics. These compounds are made up of carbon, oxygen, hydrogen and chlorine atoms. The number of the chlorine atoms and their positions in the dioxin molecule are what determines the toxicity of different dioxins. The most toxic dioxin has four chlorine atoms in positions 2, 3, 7 and 8. This dioxin ( 2, 3, 7, 8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin) is often referred to as TCDD or “dioxin”. TCDD is the most studied and the most toxic of the dioxins.
https://www.epa.gov/dioxin/learn-about-dioxin

What does plagiarism look like?•Changing a few words here and there does not avoid plagiarism!•If I can find your source using Google or Blackboard ‘TurnItIn’ –it is plagiarism!

How to avoid plagiarismUse quotations, and cite your source•“Dioxins are a group of toxic chemical compounds that share certain chemical structures and biological characteristics.” (Source:  https://www.epa.gov/dioxin/learn-about-dioxin)•“These compounds are made up of carbon, oxygen, hydrogen and chlorine atoms. The number of the chlorine atoms and their positions in the dioxin molecule are what determines the toxicity of different dioxins. The most toxic dioxin has four chlorine atoms in positions 2, 3, 7 and 8. This dioxin ( 2, 3, 7, 8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin) is often referred to as TCDD or “dioxin”. TCDD is the most studied and the most toxic of the dioxins.” (Source: https://unsolvedmysteries.oregonstate.edu/flow_02)

How to avoid plagiarismSynthesize in your own words(from previous example):Dioxins are molecules composed of carbon, oxygen, hydrogen, and chlorine atoms.  They belong to a group of chemicals which are similar in structure (their chemical composition and shape) and how they effect living organisms --including humans.  The toxicity of dioxins is determined by the number and position of the chlorine atoms; the most well know and highly toxic dioxin is known as "TCDD." (Sources: https://www.epa.gov/dioxin/learn-about-dioxin& https://unsolvedmysteries.oregonstate.edu/flow_02)

How to avoid plagiarism•A good rule of thumb: can I explain a topic or concept to my friends and family?Try to put the information into words that people without a specialized scientific background can relate to! •Check out the USC Library’s information on plagiarism & how to avoid:  https://libraries.usc.edu/tutorial/avoiding-plagiarism•Do not“Copy and Paste” sections of text (Say no to: ⌘C + ⌘V…)•Ask me if you are not sure!

Calculating the Impact of Human Population•Our environmental effects aren’t just a matter of population size; they also depend on what kinds of resources we use and how we use them. •This concept is summarized as the I = PAT formula.Our environmental impacts(I) are the product of our population size(P) times affluence(A) and technology(T). •Population = Population size•Affluence = level of consumption (goods) per person•Technology = waste & pollution from production of goods•Which component (P , A or T) results in the most negative environmental impacts?•For more information, view the following short (< 5 minutes) YouTube video presentation on the I=PAT equation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KOaS2vTLeeA

www.footprintnetwork.org

Ecological Footprints Can Calculate ImpactBesides I=PAT, another way to estimate our environmental impacts is to express our consumption choices into the equivalent amount of land required to produce goods and services. This gives us a single number, called our ecological footprint,which estimates the relative amount of productive land required to support each of us. For example, forests and grasslands store carbon, protect watersheds, purify our water, and provide wildlife habitat.

What is science? How is it done?
10Why do these questions matter?◦So you can understand the language scientists use◦So you understand the limits of scientific inquiry◦So you can determine reliability of scientific results◦So you can reject junk science◦So we can agree on facts in order to have meaningful debate

Science is a process of discoveryScience is the effort to understand the parts of the natural world that can be understood by using the processes of science/physical evidence (scientific method)Science is based on facts –shared empirical observations, experiences, objects and events (data). The foundation on which scientific knowledge is builtWhat Is Science?

Characteristics of scienceConsistent –does the phenomenon always occurs?Observable –can you experience or measure the phenomenon with your senses or technologyNatural –natural cause or mechanism must be used to explain phenomenon, not supernaturalPredictable –because there is a natural mechanisms, outcomes can be predictedTestable –must be able to test hypotheses with experiments (the process of science)Tentative –scientific theories are subject to revision and correction
12

THE PROCESS OF SCIENCE◦There are two main scientific approaches:◦Discoveryor Observationalscience is mostly about describing nature.◦Hypothesis-drivenscience is mostly about explaining nature.◦Both involve collecting data -recorded observations or items of information

Hypothesis-Driven Science•Most modern scientific investigations can be described as hypothesis-driven science.–A hypothesis is a tentative answer to a question—an explanation on trial.–Tested with experiment–Uses deductive reasoning (if…, then…)

The steps of scientific inquiry
Access the text alternative for these imagesScience is an iterative and collaborative process

Hypothesis testing (statistics!)Alternate hypothesis –what you want to test, i.e.,  there is a relationship between X and Y; X is caused by Y; treatment X and Y have different outcomes, etc.Null hypothesis -the specific prediction that there is no difference or no relationshipbetween two things, i.e., X and Y are not related; X is not cause by Y; treatment X and Y have the same outcomes, etc.Hypothesis testing = experiment to determine if you accept or reject the null hypothesis.  Eliminating possibilities!You cannot ever prove your alternate hypothesis, only provide support for it.
16

Experimentsupportshypothesis;make morepredictionsand test.ObservationPlants don’t grow on copper mine tailingsHypothesisCopper is toxic to plantsQuestionWhat’swrong?ExperimentTest different copper solutions on plant growthPredictionCopper will reduce plant growth.Plant growth stunted!  Supports hypothesis but does not proveit –all alternative explanations were not eliminated

Experimentdoes notsupporthypothesis.Experimentsupportshypothesis;make morepredictionsand test.ObservationPlants don’t grow on copper mine tailingsHypothesisCopper is toxic to plantsQuestionWhat’swrong?ExperimentTest different copper solutions on plant growth.PredictionCopper will reduce plant growthRevise.

The steps of scientific inquiry
Access the text alternative for these imagesScience is an iterative and collaborative process

Hypothesis, Theory, LawHypothesis:◦An explanation for an observation that is capable of being disproved through experiments. Theory (e.g., evolution, germ theory)◦An explanationfor a body of observations, based on evidence, repeatedly tested and widely accepted (consensus)Law (e.g., laws of thermodynamics, law of gravity)◦A descriptionof patterns/behaviors of the natural world◦Theory vs. Law: not distinguished by degree of verification

Scientific consensusScientific process does not prove anything, it excludes other possibilities.With more evidence, the case for a particular hypothesis becomes stronger, until the community reaches a consensus (scientific consensus, think evolution or climate change)Consensus can, and has, changed over time (new instruments, new experiments, etc.)

Biomolecules (Macromolecules)
Carbonis a special element because chains and rings of carbon atoms form the skeletons of organic compounds(C-C and C-H covalent bonds), the material of which biomolecules, and therefore living organisms, are made.•Also referred to as macromolecules•The four major categories of organic compounds in living things are:•Carbohydrates •Nucleic acids•Proteins•Lipids•3-minute video about macromolecules: https://youtu.be/V5hhrDFo8Vk

Permission required for reproduction or display.Four Categories of Organic Molecules (1)1.Carbohydrates(including sugars and starches) also store energy and provide structure to cells. They usually consist of a long chains of simple sugars like glucose.2.4. Nucleotides are complex molecules made of a 5-carbon sugar, one or more phosphate groups, and a nitrogen-containing base. Nucleotides are extremely important as signaling molecules and as sources of energywithin cells. They also form long chains called nucleic acids (RNA or DNA) thatstore and express genetic information.

Copyright © The McGraw-Hill Companies, Inc. Permission required for reproduction or display.Four Categories of Organic Molecules (2)3. Proteinsare composed of chains of amino acids folded into complex 3-D shapes. Proteins provide structure to cells and are used for countless cell functions, including enzymes.4. Lipids(including fats and oils) store energy for cells and provide the core of cell membranes and other structures.

Ecosystem Ecology•Ecosystem: The combination of all the organisms in a given area and the abiotic elements which affect them•An ecosystem is open –exchange can occur with other ecosystems (energy, nutrients)•Ecosystem ecology: study of ecosystem function (primary production, secondary production, nutrient cycling) and controls on/patterns of ecosystem function

Biological productionBiological Production (or Growth)The capture of usable energy from the environment and production of organic compounds to store that energy (gC/yr; kcal/yr2)•Often referred to as energy “fixation”•BiomassThe total amount of organic matter in any ecosystem or area. (gC/m2) or (MT/ha)Usually measured as amount per surface area

Primary Production (photosynthesis)

Secondary Production and RespirationSecondary Production (heterotrophs)•Cannot make their own organic compounds, therefore must feed on other living thingsOrganisms use organic compounds to grow new biomass (secondary production) and for respiration; the rest is wasteRespiration–release of useful energy from chemical bonds to fuel cellular processes•Autotrophs make their own organic matter to fuel respiration, heterotrophs get organic matter from other living things

Quantifying  Production in Systems•Gross Primary Production (GPP) –total amount of CO2fixed in an ecosystem•Net Primary Production (NPP) –energy captured that is turned into biomass•NPP = GPP –respiration(autotrophs)

Food Chains, Food Webs, and Trophic Levels Link SpeciesIn ecosystems, some consumers feed on a single species, but most consumers have multiple food sources. Similarly, some species are prey to a single kind of predator, but many species in an ecosystem are consumed by several types of predators and parasites. In this way, individual food chains become interconnected to form a food web.

Real world applications•Biomagnification of toxins•Toxins that cannot be metabolized (and generally are stored in fats) get concentrated up the food chain•More trophic levels mean greater toxin concentration•E.g., DDT, PCBs, dioxin, mercury

Real world applications•Carbon footprint of diet•Eating other consumers (e.g., cows) requires more energy•Thus, a meat-heavy diet is associated with much greater carbon emissions than a vegetarian diet•You could always eat bugs…

Biogeochemical Cycles and Life ProcessesThe elements and compounds that sustain us are cycled endlessly through living things and through the environment. On a global scale, this movement is referred to as biogeochemical cycling.

Biogeochemical cyclesThe path matter takes through the four major components –or reservoirs –of Earth’s systems1.Atmosphere2.Hydrosphere (oceans, rivers, lakes, groundwaters, and glaciers)3.Lithosphere (rocks and soils)4.Biosphere (plants, animals, bacteria & fungus)

Elements of biogeochemical cycles•Pools (reservoirs)•e.g., NH4+in the ocean•e.g., Particulate phosphorus in terrestrial plants•e.g., carbon in atmosphere•Fluxes (rates of movement between pools)•e.g., fossil fuel burning (releasing CO2)•e.g., herbivores eating plants•e.g., runoff of terrestrial nitrogen & phosphorous into aquatic ecosystems

Carbon Capture Stores CO2but is ExpensiveIt is possible, though expensive, to store CO2by injecting it deep into geologic formations. Since 1996, Norway’s Statoil has been pumping more than 1 million metric tons of CO2per year into an aquifer 1,000 meters below the seafloor in the North Sea. Energy Efficiency and ConservationMore on this when we talk about climate change

Energy Efficiency and ConservationIt’s often said that the cheapest form of energy is conservation. Energy reductions are not as visible or exciting as a power plant or a dam, but they can “produce” just as much available energy just by avoiding inefficient uses.Conservation can save money as well as reducing our energy footprint.

Costs Depend On How You Calculate Them•Much of the energy we consume is wasted.•Our ways of using energy are so inefficient that most potential energy in fuel is lost as waste heat.•Conservation involves technology innovation as well as changes in behavior, but we have met these challenges in the past. •High-efficiency automobiles are now available. Low-emission, hybrid gas-electric vehicles get up to 72 miles per gallon(30.3 kilometers/liter) on the highway.•Walking, biking, or taking public transport can lower your personal energy footprint far more.

What does passive housing involve?  Some principles:No thermal bridges (wood or metal components conduct heat through walls, roof, or foundation) Roof and wall insulation 24 to 32 centimeters (10 to 14 inches) thickWell-sealed windows and doors to prevent heat loss or gainHeat exchangers, to warm or cool fresh air as it is exchangedwith stale air leaving the buildingTriple-pane windows that reduce radiativeheat loss or gainWindows well positioned to let in daylight

Passive Housing Is Becoming Standard In Some AreasGermany has long been a leader in energy innovation and efficiency.•Passivhaus(passive house) standards were first developed there in the 1980sThese standards are strict energy use limits, along with guidelines for building practices that reduce energy consumption to just 10 percent of what normal buildings useIn the U.S., incentives, such as faster permitting or tax breaks to building projects that meet passive standards (or carbon neutrality), are increasingly common.•Decarbonizing commercial and residential construction in California:  https://ww2.arb.ca.gov/our-work/programs/building-decarbonization

Moving Water Is One Of Out Oldest Power SourcesWater power(hydropower) was our first industrial power source. Most early American settlements were built where falling water could drive gristmills and sawmills.The invention of water turbines in the nineteenth century greatly increased the efficiency of electricity-producing hydropower dams. By 1925 falling water generated 40 percent of the world’s electric power. Today, hydropower accounts for 50% of US renewable electricity, and 7% of total US electricity production•14% of global electricity production•Brazil, China, Laos and Bhutan are top hydroelectricity producersHydropower does not directlyproduce greenhouse gases!
https://www.studentenergy.org/topics/hydro-power

But,Hydroelectric Dams Have Large Impacts•Flooded river valleys•Displace communities•Indigenous communities are particularly threatened•Destroy biodiversity & sites of cultural heritage•Restricted water flow below the dam•Threatens salmon and other fish populations•E.g., sockeye salmon from the Columbia River•Interfere with recreational use of rivers•Methane (!) emissions from decaying submerged vegetation•Catastrophic downstream flooding from dam breach/failure

Solar Energy

Solar Thermal Systems Collect Useable HeatSolar power has always been our ultimate energy source.The average amount of solar energy that reaches the earth’s surface is about 10,000 times all the commercial energy used each year. This amount varies geographically, but solar energy is sufficient for economical production even at high latitudes, as in northern Europe.
U.S. Solar Resources

CSP Makes Electricity From HeatSolar thermal systems can produce extremely hot water, hot enough to make steam and run a turbine in concentrating solar power (CSP) systems. CSP often uses long, trough-shaped, parabolic mirrors to reflect and concentrate sunlight on a central tube containing a heat-absorbing fluid. Reaching extremely high temperatures, the fluid passes through a heat exchanger, where it heats water and generates steam. The steam turns a turbine to produce electricity. Heat from the transfer fluid also can be stored in a medium such as molten salt for later use. This allows the system to continue to generate electricity on cloudy days or at night.

Photovoltaic Cells Generate Electricity DirectlyPhotovoltaic (PV) cells capture solar energy and convert it directly to electrical current by separating electrons from their parent atoms and accelerating them across a one-way electrostatic barrier formed by the junction between two different types of semiconductor material.

Incoming Solar Radiation•The sun’s radiation is called solar radiation.•Sun emits and sends two main forms of radiation that are both short-wave and high-energy:•visible radiation•UV radiation•Earth’s atmosphere (aside from ozone) is basically transparent to this radiation•allows short wavelength, high energy light to pass through

Radiation and the Electromagnetic Spectrum
Governed by basic radiation laws:•All objects, above a temperature of absolute zero, emit radiation.•The hotter the radiating body, the shorter (and more intense) the wavelength of maximum radiation •The Sun (hotter) = short-wave radiation•The Earth (cooler) = emits long-wave•Objects that are good absorbers are good emitters.

Outgoing Terrestrial Radiation•Earth absorbs about 50% of this incoming solar radiation.•When Earth absorbs this radiation, it becomes heat.•After a short lag-time, Earth re-radiates infrared radiationback towards space, called terrestrial radiation.•Infrared radiation has longer waves and less energy.•Unlike the shorter solar radiation, longer terrestrial radiation is absorbed by certain gases in the atmosphere, called greenhouse gases(water vapor, methane, CFCs, CO2, and more).

Putting it all Together: the Greenhouse Effect•When longwave terrestrial radiation (heat) is absorbed by the greenhouse gases, some is re-radiated back toward Earth–keeping Earth and its atmosphere warm.•This heating of the atmosphere is termed the Greenhouse Effect .

Copyright © The McGraw-Hill Companies, Inc. Permission required for reproduction or display.The Greenhouse EffectIf our atmosphere didn’t capture this reemitted energy, the earth’s average surface temperature would be about ()6 C 21 F-°°, rather than thecurrent ()14 C 57 F°°average.Thus, energy capture is necessary for liquid water on earth and for life as we know it. The greenhouse effectis a common term to describe the capture of energy by gases in the atmosphere.

TheGreenhouse Effect: Good or Bad?•It is a GOOD thing–without it, we would bake during the day and freeze at night–not conditions suitable for life as we know it!•Too many greenhouse gases become a BAD thing–called a Runaway Greenhouse Effect--as more and more heat becomes trapped in the atmosphere–making the planet become warmer and warmer.•Venus (96% CO2) has a runaway greenhouse effect.

Venus and Earth: Results of Very Different  Greenhouse Effects•Atmosphere:•Earth  = 0.04% CO₂ •Venus = 96% CO₂ •Temperature:•Earth  =  61°F•Venus = 870°F•Water:•Earth  =  All forms•Venus = None•Life: •Earth  =  Abundance•Venus = NoneVenus facts: https://space-facts.com/venus/European Space Agency Venus Mission: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7YUy2k-edEo

Water and wind are the Leading Cause of Soil LossErosion is an important natural process that redistributes the products of geologic weathering. Erosion by water comes in many forms:•Sheet erosion removes a thin layer of soil.•Channel erosion occurs water movement creates small (rill) and large (gully) channels in the soil.•Streambankerosionalso is a problem in farmland streams, where soil washes away from stream banks.
Streambank erosion

Wind is a Close Second in ErosionWind can equal or exceed water in erosive force, especially in dry regions where vegetation is sparse. When plant cover and surface litter are removed from the land by agriculture or grazing, wind lifts loose soil particles and sweeps them away.  Can lead to desertification.Intensive farming practices are largely responsible for this situation. Row crops leave soil exposed for much of the growing season and heavy herbicide application creates weed-free fields that look tidy but are subject to erosion.
Wind erosion

High Yields Usually Require IrrigationAgriculture uses at least two-thirds of all fresh water withdrawn from rivers, lakes, and groundwater. Although estimates vary widely, about 15 percent of all cropland, worldwide, is irrigated.Irrigationin California’s Central Valley: producing more than half of US fruits, nuts and vegetables.Irrigation contributes todepletion of groundwater & aquifers

Permission required for reproduction or display.The Downside of IrrigationExcessive irrigation not only wastes water but also often results in:•Waterloggingoccurs when soil is saturated with water and plant rootsdie from lack of oxygen.•Salinization, which causes mineral salts accumulate in the soil, is often a problem when irrigation water dissolves and mobilizes salts in the soil. As the water evaporates, it leaves behind a salty crust on the soil surface that is lethal to most plants.

Copyright © The McGraw-Hill Companies, Inc. Permission required for reproduction or display.Fertilizer Boosts ProductionPlants require small amounts of inorganic nutrients from soil. In large-scale farming, fertilizers are used to ensure a sufficient supply of these nutrients.The major elements required by most plants are nitrogen, potassium, phosphorus, calcium, magnesium, and sulfur.Much of the doubling in worldwide crop production since 1950 has come from increased inorganic fertilizer use.

Over-fertilizing is Also a Common ProblemGrowing plants can use only limited amounts of nutrients, and the nutrients not captured by crops run off offields or seep into groundwater. Excess fertilizers contaminate drinking water and destabilize aquatic ecosystems (cultural eutrophication)Nitrate levels in groundwater have risen to dangerous levels in many areas where intensive farming is practiced.Inorganic nitrogen fertilizers are produced from fossil fuels
https://theconversation.com/how-your-diet-contributes-to-nutrient-pollution-and-dead-zones-in-lakes-and-bays-118902

Modern AgricultureRuns on Fossil FuelsThe food system in the United States consumes about 16% of the total energy we use. Our foods require more energy to produce, process, and get to market than they yield when we eat them.Each hectare of corn produced in the U.S. consumes the equivalent of 800 liters of oil (5 barrels of oil). •One-third of this energy is used in producing nitrogen fertilizers from natural gas.•One-third is for machinery and fuel.•One-third is used for irrigation, synthetic herbicides, and other fertilizers.Agriculture is responsible for 9% of US GHG emissions.  From:•Soilmanagement: 46%•Enteric fermentation (cow farts): 30%•Manuremanagement: 14%

Pesticide Use Continues to RiseBiological pests reduce crop yields and spoil as much as ½ of the crops harvested every year in some areas. Modern agriculture largely depends on toxic chemicals to kill or drive away these pests. Our reliance on them has grown steadily over the years.Indiscriminate pesticide use, however, also has caused many problems, such as killing non-target species, creating new pests of organisms that previously were not a problem, and causing widespread pesticide resistance among pest species.

Environmental HealthHealth is a state of complete physical, mental, and social wellbeing, not merely the absence of disease or infirmity.A disease is an abnormal change in the body’s condition that impairs important physical or psychological functions.Communicable diseases are those that can be passed from one individual to another.  Also known as contagiousor infectious diseases. Morbidity means illness.Mortality means death.Environmental health focuses on factors that cause disease, including elements of the natural, social, cultural, and technological worlds in which we live.Risk Society: “Modern society has become a risk society in the sense that it is increasingly occupied with debating, preventing and managing risks that it itself has produced.” Ulrich Beck (1986)

How and Why the Global Disease Burden is Changing•Health organizations used to focus on the leading causes of death (mortality) as a measure of world health. •Health agencies now calculate disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) as a measure of disease burden. •Also a reflection of available health care resources•The world is now undergoing a dramatic epidemiological transition. •Chronic conditions, such as cardiovascular disease and cancer, no longer afflict only the developed world. •However, traditional killers—infections, maternal and perinatal (birth) complications, and nutritional deficiencies—still take a toll in developing countries.

Leading Causes of Global Disease BurdenHistorically, infectious (communicable) diseases were the leading cause of death in humans, e.g., smallpox, measles, diarrhoealdiseases (e.g., dysentery, cholera), TB, diptheria, influenzaRANK19901Respiratory infections2Diarrhea3Neonatal conditions4Heart disease5Stroke6COPD7Malaria8Tuberculosis9Malnutrition10Neonatal encephalopathy11Back and neck pain12Unintentional injuries13Congenital anomalies14Iron anaemia15DepressionRANK20201Heart disease2Respiratory infections3Stroke4Preterm birth5Diarrhea6Road injury7COPD8Diabetes9Birth trauma10Congenital anomalies11HIV/AIDS12Tuberculosis13Depression14Iron anaemia15Back and neck painSOURCE: Data from World Health Organization, 2002.https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/the-top-10-causes-of-death

Emergent and Infectious Diseases Kill ChildrenDiarrhea, acute respiratory illnesses, malaria, measles, tetanus, and other infectious diseases kill about 11 million children every year in the developing world. Better nutrition, clean water, improved sanitation, and inexpensive inoculations (vaccinations) could eliminate most of those deaths.

Success in fighting Pathogens•Through vaccines and access to clean water and sanitation, many communicable diseases have been completely or nearly eliminated, e.g.:•Smallpox (eradicated)•Polio•Measles•Mumps •Rubella•Diptheria•Guinea worm•Lymphatic filariasis (Elephantiasis)•Some communicable diseases stubbornly remain:•Tuberculosis•Malaria•HIV/AIDS•Hepatitis
https://www.who.int/health-topics/#A

Outbreaks of Infectious DiseasesMalariais one of the most prevalent remaining infectious diseases. Every year about 500 million new cases of this disease occur, and about one million people die from it.  Children are the most vulnerable.Tuberculosis(TB) infects 9 million people every year, and kills 1.5-2 millionEmergent diseases are those not previously known or that have been absent for at least 20 years.  Their spread is accelerated by high population densities.•The H1N1 new strain of bird flu that spread around the world in 2009. •There have been at least 40 outbreaks of emergent diseases over the past two decades, including the Ebola and Marburg fevers.•Coronaviruses•SARS (2003): 747 deaths (10% case fatality rate)•MERS (2012): 858 deaths (34% case fatality rate)•COVID-19 (2019): 1.11 million deaths and counting (US: 214,370+)•Seasonal flu: 24-64,000 deaths (US only)•https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/en/•https://www.cdc.gov•https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/data/mortality

Factors influencing the persistence and spread of infectious diseases•Climate change •Expansion of pathogens and pests into new territories•Global travel and trade•Diseases and pests can move easily around the world•Habitat destruction & exploitation•Increased contact between humans and population of wild animals•Concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs)•Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli O157:H7•Antibiotic resistance09/22/10

Resistance to Antibiotics and Pesticides is IncreasingIn recent years, health workers have become increasingly alarmed about the rapid spread of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), drug-resistant Tuberculosis (DR TB). Why have vectors, such as mosquitoes, and pathogens, such as bacteria or the malaria parasite, become resistant to pesticides and antibiotics? Part of the answer is natural selection and the ability of many organisms to evolve rapidly. Another factor is the human tendency to use control measures carelessly.

How Microbes Acquire Antibiotic Resistance
a)Mutation and selection create drug-resistant strains.
b)Conjugation transfers drug resistance from one strain to another.

ToxicologyToxicology is the study of the adverse effects of external factors on an organism or a system. This includes environmental chemicals, drugs, and diet as well as physical factors, such as ionizing radiation, UV light, and electromagnetic forces.Toxins often are harmful even in extremely dilute concentrations. In some cases, billionths, or even trillionths, of a gram can cause irreversible damage.Environmental toxicologyspecifically deals with the interactions, transformation, fate, and effects of toxins in the biosphere, including individual organisms, populations, and whole ecosystems.

What are toxins?•Hazardous chemicalsmay be toxic or flammable, explosive, caustic, irritants, or sensitizers.•Many can be diluted and are relatively harmless when dilute•Toxinsare ______________________ that disrupt metabolic functions in  cells of living organisms •Often harmful in very low doses (billionths or trillionths of a gram)•Natural toxins can be as toxic as synthetic ones

Copyright © The McGraw-Hill Companies, Inc. Permission required for reproduction or display.Top 20 Toxic and Hazardous SubstancesTABLE8.2Top 20 Toxic and Hazardous SubstancesMATERIALMAJOR SOURCES1.ArsenicTreated lumber2.LeadPaint, gasoline3.MercuryCoal combustion4.Vinyl chloridePlastics, industrial uses5.Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs)Electric insulation6.BenzeneGasoline, industrial use7.CadmiumBatteries8.Benzo(a)pyreneWaste incineration9.Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbonsCombustion10.Benzo(b)fluorantheneFuels11.ChloroformWater purification, industry12.DDTPesticide use13.Aroclor1254Plastics14.Aroclor1260Plastics15.TrichloroethyleneSolvents16.Dibenz(a, h)anthraceneIncineration17.DieldrinPesticides18.Chromium, hexavalentPaints, coatings, welding, anticorrosion agents19.ChlordanePesticides20.HexachlorobutadienePesticidesSOURCE: Data from U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.

Classes of Harmful AgentsNeurotoxins are a special class of metabolic poisons that specifically attack nerve cells (neurons). Mutagens are agents, such as chemicals and radiation, that damage or alter genetic material (DNA) in cells.Teratogens arechemicals or other factors that specifically cause abnormalities during embryonic growth and development. Carcinogens are substances that cause cancer.

Endocrine Hormone Disrupters are of Special ConcernEndocrine hormone disruptersare chemicals that interrupt the normal endocrine hormone functions. Some of the most insidious effects of persistent organic pollutants (POPs), such as _________, are that they interfere with normal growth, development, and physiology of a variety of animals at very low doses.These chemicals are sometimes called environmental estrogensor androgens, because they often cause reproductive health problems in females or feminization of males.https://www.ewg.org/research/dirty-dozen-list-endocrine-disruptors

Movement, Distribution, and Fate of ToxinsWe can think of both individuals andan ecosystem as sets of interacting compartments between whichchemicals move, based on molecular size, solubility, stability, and reactivity

Exposure and Susceptibility Determine How we RespondThere are many routes for toxins to enter our bodies: water, food, air, consumer products.Exposure: inhaled,throughskin,ingestion, injectionAirborne toxins generally cause more ill health than any other exposure source; however, food, water, and skin contact can also expose us to a wide variety of hazards.Susceptibility:age, health status, occupationAge matters and general health matters: healthy adults, for example, may be relatively insensitive to doses that are very dangerous to young children or to someone already weakened by other diseases.

Solubility and Mobility Determine When and Where Chemicals MoveSolubility is one of the most important characteristics in determining how, a toxic material will move through the environment or through the body to its site of action.Chemicals can be divided into 2 major groups: •Water soluble compounds move rapidly and widely through the environment because water is ubiquitous.•Molecules that are oil-or fat-soluble generally need a carrier to move through the environment.

Bioaccumulation and BiomagnificationBioaccumulation refers to the fact that organismsmay selectively absorb and store toxins in their bodies.Biomagnification occurs when the toxic burden of a large number oforganisms at a lower trophic level is accumulated and concentrated by a predator at a higher trophic level.

Persistence Makes Some Materials a Greater ThreatMany substances degrade when exposed to sun, air, and water. This can destroy them or convert them to inactive forms.Some materials are persistent and can last for years or even centuries as they cycle through ecosystems.  Persistent toxins retain their toxicity.Examples:•Heavy metals: lead and mercury.•Organic compounds, such as phthalates (plasticizers), PCBs (electrical insulator), pesticides (e.g., DDT & Malathion), dioxins (industrial byproduct of pesticide manufacture, pulp and paper), PFASs perfluoroalkyl substances, (Teflon, Scotchguard) = POPs (Persistent Organic Pollutants)

Chemical Interactions can alter ToxicitySome materials produce antagonistic reactions. That is, they interfere with the effects or stimulate the breakdown of other chemicals.Other materials are additive when they occur together in exposures. Synergism is an interaction in which one substance exacerbates the effects of another.

How can toxic effects can be minimized? •Break it up, dilute it down, flush it out•Liver helps to break toxins apart (metabolic degradation)•Toxins can be diluted to sub-lethal dose –one hundred cups coffee contain a lethal dose of caffeine. •Toxins can be excretedin urine , faeces, sweat or breath•Toxins are sometimes degraded when exposed to sun, air and water•We have DNA repair mechanisms to repair damage to DNA or  apoptosisto destroy  and slough off cells that are beyond repair

Toxicity and Risk Assessment“The dose makes the poison” —this means that almost everything is toxic at very high levels, butcan be safe if diluted enough. This remains the most basic principle of toxicology. How a material is delivered and at what rate plays a vital role in determining toxicity.Even water is toxic when we consume too much: hyponatremia

We Usually Test Toxic Effects on Lab AnimalsThe most commonly used and widely accepted toxicity test is to expose a population of laboratory animals to measured doses of a specific substance under controlled conditions.It commonly takes hundreds—or even thousands—of animals, several years of hard work, and hundreds of thousands of dollars to thoroughly test the effects of a toxic at very low doses.A convenient way to describe toxicity of a chemical is to determine the dose to which 50 percent of the test population is sensitive. In the case of a lethal dose (LD), this is called the LD50.
Dose response curve

There is a Wide Range of ToxicityIt is useful to group materials according to their relative toxicity.A moderately harmful toxin takes about 1 gram per kilogram of body weight to make a lethal dose. Very toxic materials take about 1/10 of that amount.Extremely toxic materialstake 1/100 as much (only a few drops) to kill most people. Supertoxicmaterials/chemicals are extremely potent; for some, a few micrograms (millionths of a gram) is enough for a lethal dose.

Toxins Can Have Acute or Chronic Doses and EffectsAcute effects are caused by a single exposure to the toxin and result in an immediate health crisis.Chronic effects arelong-lasting, perhaps even permanent. A chronic effect can result from a single dose of a very toxic substance, or it can be the result of a continuous or repeated sublethalexposure.Unlike acute effects, it is usually difficult to assess the specific health risks of chronic exposures because other factors, such as aging or normal diseases, act simultaneously with the factor under study.

Risk Assessment and AcceptanceEven if we know with some certainty how toxic a specific chemical is in laboratory tests, it is still difficult to determine risk.Objective risk is the magnitude of harm(mortality or morbidity rate) times the probability of exposure. Public perception of environmental hazards can be inconsistent with estimates of objective risk.

How Much Risk is Acceptable?How much is it worth to minimize and avoid exposure to certain risks?The EPA generally assumes that a risk of 1 in 1 million (1 death in 1,000,000)is acceptable for most environmental hazards. For activities that we enjoy, we are often willing to accept far greater risks than this general threshold.

ENST 100 – Letter to a Decision-Maker Assignment Due by 5:00 pm on November 1 (submit to BB Turnitin)  One of the goals of higher education, is to encourage engaged and informed citizenship.  The rights that we enjoy in the US come with responsibilities (http://www.uscis.gov/citizenship/learners/citizenship-rights-and-responsibilities), some of which are:  1) Stay informed of the issues affecting your community. 2) Participate in the democratic process. 3) Participate in your local community. 4) Engage in active environmental citizenship.  If you care about the state of the environment and the protection of it, you must be informed about the issues and participate in the processes that can bring about change.  To this end, I would like you to write a letter to a decision-maker (e.g., a member of federal, state, local or tribal government, a business leader, or a leader from a non-governmental organization) expressing your views on a particular environmental problem and how you think it should be solved. The letter will be formatted as a formal letter to this individual, and should be as persuasive as possible. You will provide evidence to express the importance of this issue, as well as how you propose it should be addressed. Extra credit will be given for actually sending your letter.   If you choose to write to an elected official, you can write about a specific bill that is being considered (try https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/ for lists of current legislation) or more generally about an issue that you feel strongly about (like the need to vote for bills that support solutions to climate change).  The issue does not necessarily have to be a global one, but could be something that is important in your hometown area.  You can write to your own representative or senator, or to a congressperson in a district where some environmental issue that is important to you is occurring, but the letter must be to a specific legislator.    You must use as much scientific evidence and reasoning as possible in your arguments.  Please cite your sources for evidence with footnotes.  The letter should be properly formatted and addressed to the decision-maker.  Instructions for a general purpose business/professional letter can be found here: https://owl.purdue.edu/owl/subject_specific_writing/professional_technical_writing/basic_business_letters/index.html  Instructions for a letter to a US government representative can be found here: https://www.thoughtco.com/write-effective-letters-to-congress-3322301    This assignment will be worth ~6% of your grade and will be graded for content, writing style, and format.  Length will not specifically be graded, but the letter should be about 1.5 pages (single spaced, as letters are not double spaced) in order to make your argument sufficiently.  Extra credit will be given if you send proof that you actually sent the letter!  (e.g., attach a picture with your Blackboard submission that shows a screenshot of online submission)   Citations as numbered footnotes

Permission required for reproduction or display.The Clean Air Act Regulates Major PollutantsIn 1970, The Clean Air Act designated new air quality standards, to be applied equally across the country, for six major pollutants. These six are referred to as conventional or criteria pollutants, and they include sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, carbon monoxide, ozone (and its precursor volatile organic compounds), lead, and particulate matter.Standards based on human health and environmental criteriaTransportation and power plants are the dominant sources of most criteria pollutants.

History of the Clean Air Act•Clean Air Act of 1963 was the first U.S. legislation aimed at air pollution controlØGoals: decrease ambient air pollution, decrease toxic pollutants and decrease ozone-destroying chemicals•1970, extensive set of amendments essentially rewrote the Clean Air ActØdesignated standards for criteria pollutantsand unconventional pollutants•1990, Further amendmentsØdesigned to address urban air pollution, acid rain, and toxic air emissions•2009, following a Supreme Court Ruling, CO2and other greenhouse gases to list of regulated pollutants9-9Los Angeles: 1968 and 2005http://cires.colorado.edu/news/press/los-angeles-air-pollution-declining-losing-its-sting/Throughout its history the Clean Air Act has been controversial. Victims of air pollution demand more protection; industry and special interest groups complain that controls are too expensive.

How the EPA Regulates Air Pollution•EPA sets limits on pollutants, approves state, tribal and local plans to abate pollutants•NAAQS: National Ambient Air Quality Standards, based on:•Primary Standards (human health)•Secondary Standards (environment & property)•Advice on these standards(and the science behind them) provided the Clean Air Scientific Advisory Committee

Other Pollution SourcesA point source is a smokestack or some other concentrated pollution origin. Fugitive ornonpoint-source emissions are those that do not go through a smokestack.  Examples:•Leaking valves and pipe joints contribute as much as 90% of the hydrocarbons and volatile organic chemicals emitted from oil refineries and chemical plants, and increasingly from natural gas wells. •Dust, as from mining, agriculture, and building construction and demolition, is also considered fugitive emissions.

Indoor Air Pollution•The EPA has found that indoor concentrations of toxic air pollutants are often higher than outdoors. •In some cases, would be illegal outside or in the workplace.•People generally spend more time inside than out and therefore are exposed to higher doses of these pollutants. •Developed countries: Smoking is the most important air pollutant •Developing areas: Organic fuels used indoors for heating and cooking fires represent the largest problem.•Under some circumstances, some pollutants can be 70 X higher in indoor air than in outdoor air. •Molds, pathogens, and other biohazards also represent serious indoor pollutants.

Natural Sources of Air Pollution•There are also many natural sources of air quality degradation:•Fires release smoke & PM. •Bacterial metabolism of decaying materials is responsible for large methane releases. •Forest fires and the microbial release of methane are expected to increase with climate change•Volcanic eruptions release ash, acid mists, hydrogen sulfide, and other toxic gases. •Immediately deadly for those in the immediate area, can also disrupt air travel

Air Pollution: Acid Precipitation•Acid rain –SOx(SO2& SO4) & NOx react with water to form acidic precipitation (composed of nitric and sulfuric acid)•pH 7 is neutral•“natural” rain is slightly acidic at ~ 5.6 because carbon dioxide dissolves into atmospheric moisture•acid rain as low as pH 1.7 has been measured!•Deposition of acidic droplets or particles, from rain, fog, snow, or aerosols in the atmosphere, became recognized as a widespread pollution in the 1980s.•Acidic deposition is now understood to affect forests, aquatic systems, and agricultural production far from industrial centers.•Ongoing exposure to acid fog, snow, mist, and dew cause permanent damage to plants, lake ecosystems, and buildings.

Acid Precipitation•Acid precipitation has many effects–Acid precipitationbecame widely recognized as a pollution problem only in the last 20 years.–The most notable aquatic effects of acid deposition are the reduction of trout, salmon, and other game fish, whose eggs and young die below pH 5.–Forest damage: On Mount Mitchell in North Carolina, nearly all the trees above 2,000 m (6,000 ft) are losing needles, and about half are dead.–Acids dissolve limestone and marble, destroying features and structures of historic buildings.–Costs are estimated at several billion dollars per year!

Energy ResourcesModern life runs on energy.Electricity and abundant fuel make our lives better by providing heating, cooling, and transportation.We use energy to grow and prepare food, to work at our jobs, and to entertain ourselves. Fossil fuels—oil, gas, and coal—provide the bulk of this energy. Hydropower and nuclear power supplement these, and increasingly wind, solar, and other renewable forms of energy are part of our standard energy supply.

Fossil Fuels Supply Most of Our EnergyLike most other industrialized nations, the U.S. gets a vast majority of its energy from fossil fuels. Oil makes up 36.2% of this supply, while natural gas (28%) and coal (14%) follow close behind.Renewables make up only 11% of U.S. power.

Formation of Fossil FuelsFossil fuels are organic (carbon-based) compounds derived from decomposed plants, algae, and other organisms buried in rock layers for hundreds of millions of years.Most of the richest deposits date to about 286 million to 360 million years ago (the Mississippian, Pennsylvanian, and Permian periods: when the Earth’s climate was much warmer and wetter than it is now.
https://youtu.be/zaXBVYr9Ij0
Types of fossil fuelsCoalCrude Oil (Petroleum)Natural Gas
Peat and Coal Form as Sediment Buries Organic Litter in a Swamp

Coal Resources Are Greater Than We Can UseWorld coal deposits are enormous, ten times greater than conventional oil and gas resources combined.Almost all the world's coal is in North America, Europe and Asia and just three countries, the U.S., Russia, and China, account for 2/3 of all proven reserves.The total resource is estimated to be 10 trillion metric tons--a several thousand years’ supply.But coal mining is a dirty, dangerous activity.

Coal mining is dirty, dangerous activity
Mountaintop Removal mining (Appalachia)
Underground mining (Ohio)What kind of mining is this?

Coal Burning Releases Huge Amounts of Air PollutionEvery year the roughly one billion tons of coal burned in the U.S. releases close to a trillion metric tons of carbon dioxide (CO2).This is about half of the industrial CO2released by the United States each year.Coal also contains toxic impurities, such as mercury, arsenic, chromium, and lead, which are released into the air during combustion.  Contributes to particulate matter pollution (PM2.5& PM10.It’s possible to make either gas or liquid fuels out of coal, but these processes are even dirtier and more expensive than burning the coal directly.

Coal Use Is Declining In The U.S.Coal is fading quickly from our energy picture.Projected to supply less than 1/5 of US electricity this year (2020).Replaced by growth in Natural Gas & RenewablesOnly half a dozen new coal-fired power plants are now under construction or in the planning stage. And when the last of those plants is finished about five years from now, no other new projects are proposed for the foreseeable future.Federal regulations are part of this decline.2012 EPA Mercury and Air Toxics Standards and proposed limitations on carbon emissions are making coal plants more expensive to operate.National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) for PMStates and cities are signing on to international pacts to reduce carbon emissions, achieve carbon neutrality, e.g., C40 cities (https://www.c40.org/about)

Energy Resources: Petroleum
(A)Organic matter from land and sea settles to the sea floor and mixes with mud. (B)Younger sediment buries this organic-rich mud. Rising temperature and pressure convert the mud to shale, and the organic matter to petroleum.(C)The petroleum is trapped in the reservoir by an impermeable cap rock like a soaked sponge. 
shale
What kind of rock is shale?  Igneous, sedimentary or metamorphic?

Problems With Petroleum
•Toxicity: Petroleum components (like benzene) known to cause cancer.•Waste oil contaminates water sources.•Exhaust is a pollution from incomplete combustion, giving off several pollutants, including CO.•Contributes to smog, surface ozone formation and acid precipitation•Removal can damage environment due to disruption, spills, etc.•Contributes to greenhouse effect and climate change (CO2)•Over 2/3 of today’s proven reserves of fossil fuels need to still be in the ground in 2050 in order to prevent catastrophic levels of climate change (International Energy Agency).

When Will We Run Out Of Oil?We have already used more than 0.5 trillion barrel—almost half of proven oil reserves. The remainder is expected to last 40-60 years at current consumption rates of 30.7 billion barrel per year.

US Oil Production has been increasing
https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=40032

Worldwide oil production and consumption
https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=709&t=6

UnconventionalOil Sources Extend Our SuppliesThe World Energy Council estimates that oil shales, tar sands, and other unconventional deposits contain 10X as much oil as liquid petroleum reserves.This costly, energy-intensive extraction becomes economically justified when oil prices are at $100 per barrel

Tar Sands (Alberta, Canada)
Tar sands are composed of sand and shale particles coated with bitumen, a viscous mixture of long-chain hydrocarbons. Shallow tar sands are excavated and mixed with hot water and steam to extract the bitumen. About oil sands mining: https://youtu.be/cxiA40XHF0I

Energy Resources: Oil Shale•Oil shales are fine-grained sedimentary rock rich in solid organic material called kerogen. Like tar sands, the kerogen can be heated, liquefied, and pumped out like liquid crude oil.•Just CO, WY and UT could provide enough oil to US for 100 years, or several trillion barrels of oil.•Oil shale in Texas Permian Basin driving oil boom there too

Oil Shales and Tar Sands HaveLarge Environmental & Social CostsThere are severe environmental costs, though.  A typical plant creates:•about 15 million m3of toxic sludge•releases 5,000 tons of greenhouse gases•consumes billions of liters of water each year.Both sands and shales require copious amounts of water (2 barrels water  = 1 barrel oil) and high energy inputs to extract (1 unit of nat.gastoproduce3units bitumen)
https://www.nationalobserver.com/2018/11/23/news/alberta-officials-are-signalling-they-have-no-idea-how-clean-toxic-oilsands-tailings

Energy Resources: Natural Gas•Natural gas –forms when source rock containing crude oil rises above 100°C (212°F)•Often found with crude oil deposits•Mainly methane, used as fuel without processing•Cleaner burning than oil, coal: half as much CO2•Leaky pipes could offset gains in carbon pollution

Natural Gas is the World’s Third Largest Commercial Fuel•Because natural gas produces only half as much CO2as an equivalent amount of coal, substitution could help reduce global warming.•More than half of all the world’s proven natural gas reserves are in the Middle East and the former Soviet Union.•The total proved natural gas reserves in the world are estimated to be 7177 trillion ft3. Current gas reserves represent roughly a 60-year supply at present usage rates.

Hydraulic Fracturing Opens Up Tight Gas ResourcesWhen shale deposits are in “tight” formations, gas doesn’t flow easily. To boost well output, mining companies rely on hydraulic fracturing (or “fracking”). A mixture of water, sand, and various chemicals is pumped into the ground and rock formations at extremely high pressure. The pressurized fluid cracks sediments and releases the gas.

Hydraulic Fracturing•Positive:economic benefits from vast amounts of formerly inaccessible hydrocarbons•Negative:potential environmental impacts, including:•contamination of ground water and wells•risks to air quality•the migration of gases and hydraulic fracturing chemicals to the surface•contamination from spills•earthquakes, other “fraccidents”•uses a lot of water•Some states have banned it, or are in the process of banning it, e.g., California, Maryland, NY State,
About hydraulic fracturing:https://youtu.be/G1PBYlxcF0M

Nuclear PowerIn 1953 President Dwight Eisenhower presented his “Atoms for Peace” speech to the United Nations. He announced that the United States would build nuclear-powered electrical generators to provide clean, abundant energy. Today there are about 440 reactors in use worldwide, 104 of these in the United States.Half of the U.S. plants (52) are more than 30 years old and are thus approaching the end of their expected operational life.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ta3z3pGK0vU

How Do Nuclear Reactors Work?Radioactive uranium atoms are unstable—when struck by a high-energy neutron, they undergo nuclear fission (splitting),releasing energy and more neutrons causing a self-sustaining chain reaction.

Pressurized Water Nuclear Reactor
1.Fuel rods containing Uranium 235 are placed in water in reactor core, interspersed with neutron-absorbing control rods, containing boron or cadmium.2.When control rods are raised, a chain reaction of nuclear fission occurs in fuel rods, creating heat.3.High-pressure, superheated water flows to a heat exchanger, which generates steam in a separate, secondary loop.4.Steam turns a turbine, which turns an electricity generator.
5.Cooling water condenses steam to water, which returns to the heat exchanger.Access the text alternative for these images

Nuclear Disasters Can Happen
Fukushima Daiichi, Japan (March 2011)
Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plan, Ukraine (May 1989)

We Lack Safe Storage for Radioactive WasteOne of the most difficult problems associated with nuclear power is the disposal of wastes produced during mining, fuel production, and reactor operation.How these wastes are managed may ultimately be the overriding obstacle to nuclear power.

Earth is a Dynamic PlanetCrust is the outermost cool, lightweight, brittle layer of the Earth.•8-15 km thick below the oceans; 25-75 km thick below the continents  •Composed of granitic & basaltic (igneous) rockMantle surrounds the molten outer core, and is a hot, pliable layer of rock.•Approximately 2900 km thick•Mostly composed of Magnesium, Silicon & OxygenThe core is composed of a dense, intensely hot mass of metal—mostly iron.•Core has a radius of approx. 3500 km•Composed of Iron & Nickel (both solid & liquid)

Tectonic Processes Reshape Continents and Cause EarthquakesThe Earth’s crust is divided into a mosaic of huge blocks called tectonic plates.These plates slide slowly across the Earth’s surface like wind-driven ice sheets on water.Magma (molten rock) forced up through the cracks forms new oceanic crust that piles up underwater in mid-ocean ridges.Earthquakes, such as the ones that struck Japan in 2011, are caused by jerking as plates grind past each other.

EnvironmentalEffects of Resource ExtractionThe most obvious effect of mining (and drilling for fossil fuels) is often the disturbance or removal of the land surface. Farther-reaching effects, though, include air and water pollution.The EPA lists more than 100 toxic air pollutants released from U.S. mines and wells every year.Sediment runoff and acidic mine runoff has damaged or destroyed aquatic ecosystems in many places.After use in ore processing, much of the rinse water contains arsenic, cyanide, heavy metals (e.g., mercury, lead), and other contaminants and is unsuitable for any other use.

Underground miningThere are many techniques for extracting geologic materials. The most common methods are open-pit mining, underground mining, and strip mining. From underground mining:  tin, lead, copper, coal With underground mining, water seeps into mine shafts and can dissolve toxic minerals and then seep into groundwater or enter streams and lakes.For people working in underground mines, there is always the threat of tunnel collapse or explosions due to natural gas accumulation.

Open-pit Surface Mining Destroys LandscapesOpen-pit mines are used to extract massive beds of metal ores and other minerals.From open pit mines: copper, gold, iron, aluminumA chief environmental challenge of open-pit mining is that groundwater accumulates in the pit. In metal mines, a toxic soup results. No one yet knows how to detoxify these lakes which endanger wildlife and nearby watersheds.

Strip MiningHalf the coal used in the United States comes from strip mines.The entire land surface covering a coal bed can be stripped away to cheaply and quickly expose the coal. The overburden, or surface material, is placed back into the mine, but with no topsoil, re-vegetation occurs very slowly.The 1977 Federal Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act (SMCRA) requires better restoration of strip-mined lands, but restoration is expensive.

Legacy of an Idaho silver mine
•Mine tailings: material left over from mining activity•Material may be toxic, so nothing grows on them•May take 100’s years for the landscape to recover•Material may also be unstable, resulting in a landslidehttps://www.spokaneriverkeeper.org/toxics/silver-valley-mining

Conserve & Recycle Geologic Resources!Conservation offers great potential for extending our supplies of economic minerals and reducing the effects of mining and processing.The advantages of conservation are significant: less waste to dispose of, less land lost to mining, and less consumption of money, energy, and water resources.•Today, nearly 2/3 of all aluminum beverage cans in the United States are recycled, up from only 15 percent 20 years ago.•Other commonly recycled metals are gold, silver, copper, lead, iron, and steel.

In 2004 an earthquake and tsunami off the coast of Indonesia, for example, killed over 230,000 people.About 25,000 people were killed and four nuclear reactors were destroyed by the 2011 Japanese tsunami.

Aquatic Biomes

Marine Biome•The largest biome•Within this biome, marine communities depend on photosynthetic organisms called phytoplankton.•Phytoplankton: tiny, free-floating photosynthetic algae often support a marine food web rather than trees or grasses.•In oceans, photosynthetic activity tends to be greatest near coastlines, where nitrogen, phosphorus, and other nutrients wash offshore and fertilize primary producers.

What Influences the Location of the Major Marine Communities?•Light•Temperature•Nutrients•Nutrient (and fertilizer) runofffrom land (N & P) •Upwellingfrom benthic region of deep ocean•Oxygen(more in colder waters)•Pressure•Light and temperature decreasewith depth•Most productive marine ecosystems are near the surface (coral reefs, estuaries)
Nutrients from land

Open Ocean Communities Vary from Surface to Hadal ZoneOcean systems can be described by depth and proximity to shore:•Benthic communities occur on the bottom.•Pelagic zones are the water column.The epipelagic zone has photosynthetic organisms. •Light is attenuated quicklyBeloware the mesopelagicand bathypelagic zones. Thedeepest layers are the abyssal zone (to 4,000 meters) and hadal zone (deeper than 6,000 meters). Shorelines are known as littoral zones, and the area exposed by low tides is known as the intertidal zone.

•Coral reefs–coral animals in symbiosis with algae•High biodiversity•Endangered by  coastal development (sedimentation), destructive fishing methods, invasive fish, warming oceans àcoral bleaching•Sea grass beds –grass-based community, shallow seas•Mangroves–salt-tolerant trees in shallow seas, more than ½ the world’s mangroves destroyed/ degraded•stabilize shorelines, build land, blunt force of storms•Estuaries–bay where rivers empty into oceans and Saltmarshes–wetlands regularly flooded w/ sea water•2/3 marine fish and shellfish need these for spawning and fish nurseries•Tide pools –shoreline community, harsh conditions

Freshwater Biome•The freshwater biome is much smaller than the marine biome, but is a center of biodiversity. •Most terrestrial communities rely, to some extent, on freshwater ecosystems: lakes, wetlands, streams, & rivers. •In deserts, isolated ephemeral pools, streams, and even underground water systems support astonishing biodiversity as well as provide water to land animals.

Lakes Have Extensive Open WaterFreshwater lakes, like marine environments, have distinct vertical zones.Near the surface is a subcommunityof plankton, mainly microscopic plants, animals, and protists.Fish move through the water column, sometimes near the surface and sometimes at depth.Finally, the bottom, or benthos, is occupied by a variety of snails, burrowing worms, fish, and other organisms
Limnetic zone

What Influences the Distribution of Organisms Within a Lake?•Temperature•Light •Nutrients (including nutrient & fertilizer runoff), •Oxygen, •Lakes:•Limnetic zone –more oxygen and light•Benthos –little light, may have low oxygen levels•Littoral zone –shoreline, with great productivity (shallow water, lots of light + lots of nutrients)

Wetlands•Swamps, marshes, bogs, & fens•5% of total land area•Very biologically productive•Improve water quality:•Erosion control•Filter contaminants•Habitat for insects, shellfish and spawning fish & breeding birds

Wetlands are Described by Their VegetationSwamps are wetlands with trees. Marshes are wetlands without trees. Bogs are areas of water-saturated ground usually composed of deep layers of undecayed vegetation known as peat.  Found in areas with lots of precipitation.  Low pH.Fens are like bogs, but are continually replenished by groundwater.  More oxygenated, more neutral pH.

Streams and Rivers are Open SystemsStreams begin at the headwaters of a watershed.  •Source: glacial melt, groundwater, precipitation•As streams collect water and merge, they form rivers.•Rivers eventually discharge into a lake or ocean Streams are composed of riffles and pools:•Riffles –where water runs over a rocky substrate, high oxygen levels•Pools –deep, slow-moving water with lower oxygen levelsDifferent stream organisms are found in pools vs riffles –depending on their preference for oxygen levels, speed of current, and substrate.

5.4 BiodiversityBiodiversity, the variety of living things. Three kinds of biodiversity are essential to preserve ecological systems and functions:•genetic diversity is a measure of the variety of versions of the same genes within individual species.•species diversity describes the number of different kinds of organisms within a community or ecosystem.•ecological diversity refers to the richness and complexity of a biological community.Estimated total number of species on earth?

Measuring biodiversity in the environment•Species composition•What species are there?•Species richness•How many different species are there?•Species diversity•How many are there relative to the others? (richness and evenness)

Biodiversity Hot Spots are Rich and ThreatenedMost of the world’s biodiversity concentrations are near the equator, especially tropical rainforests and coral reefs. Of all the world’s species, only 10 to 15 percent live in North America and Europe. Many species have yet to be identified and studied by scientists.Areas isolated by water, deserts, or mountains can also have high concentrations of unique species and biodiversity.

Are we in the midst of a mass extinction?
13Mass extinction: when extinction rates are higher than speciation rates, causing the loss of >75% species in <2 mil. yrs.

Current Mass Extinction?•-Background: 2 mammal extinctions per 10,000 species per 100 years•-617 vertebrate extinctions since 1500 (extinct, possible extinct, extinct in the wild)•-8-100 times historic background rate•-30% of animal and plant species could be extinct by 2050Ceballos et al 2015

Benefits of Biodiversity•“Ecosystem Services”•Cultural•Provisioning•Regulatory•Supporting•“The value of ecological services is more than double the total world GNP” or $33 trillion per year•àSome scientists argue that maintaining biodiversity makes economicsense•Other scientists caution that we underappreciate & undervalue the cultural, aesthetic, educational and relational values of biodiversity.

What Threatens Biodiversity? (From E.O. Wilson)•H for habitat destruction (forests, grasslands àagriculture & human settlements)•Major threat, leads to loss and fragmentation of habitat•I for invasive species (thrive in new habitat with no predators or competitors)•Growing threat, includes Eurasian milfoil, water hyacinth, kudzu vine, Carp (Bighead, Grass, Silver), purple loosestrife, zebra mussels•P for pollution (can be long-lasting, can magnify in upper food chain)•DDT (pesticide), PCB (electrical insulation fluid), dioxins (paper industry, pesticide manufacture) lead (shotgun pellets) •P for population growth & AFFLUENCE•Consume resources•O for overharvesting (of plants and animals)•Overharvesting depletes or eliminates species, e.g., baleen whales

Many Countries Have Created Nature PreservesDifferent levels of protection are found in nature preserves. The IUCN divides protected areas into five categories depending on the intended level of allowed human use.In the most stringent category (ecological reserves and wilderness areas), little human impacts are allowed.In the least restrictive categories (national forests and other natural resource management areas), on the other hand, there may be a high level of human use. These are controversial categories, as they are often imposed on local communities with little to no consultationSee also: https://www.iucn.org/theme/protected-areas/abouthttps://www.protectedplanet.net

Endangered Species ActPassed by Congress in 1973•The purpose of the ESA is to protect and recover imperiled species and the ecosystems upon which they depend. •Administered by: The Interior Department’s U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) and the Commerce Department’s National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS)•Under the ESA, species may be listed as either endangered or threatened. “Endangered” means a species is in danger of extinction throughout all or a significant portion of its range. “Threatened” means a species is likely to become endangered within the foreseeable future. What are the criteria for deciding whether to add a species to the list?1.The present or threatened destruction, modification, or curtailment of its habitat or range;2.Overutilization for commercial, recreational, scientific, or educational purposes;3.Disease or predation;4.Inadequacy of existing regulatory mechanisms;5.Other natural or manmade factors affecting its survival.Once listed, then what happens?•Recovery Plandeveloped•Aim to rebuild population:•Buy habitat, restore habitat, reintroduce species, establish captive breeding programs•Further, the ESA makes it unlawful for a person to take a listed animal without a permit. Take is defined as “to harass, harm, pursue, hunt, shoot, wound, kill, trap, capture, or collect or attempt to engage in any such conduct.” •Through regulations, the term “harm” is defined as “an act which actually kills or injures wildlife. Such an act may include significant habitat modification or degradationwhere it actually kills or injures wildlife by significantly impairing essential behavioral patterns, including breeding, feeding, or sheltering.”

Causes of Deforesta8onA variety of factors contribute to deforestation:•Agriculture!•Cattle (beef) production•Soybean cultivation•Palm oil production•Logging for valuable tropical hardwoods, such as teak and mahogany.•Small-scale agriculture•Road building•Insects, disease, severe weather

Forest Harvest MethodsMost lumber and pulpwood in the U.S. and Canada currently are harvested by clear-cutting, in which every tree in a given area is cut, regardless of size.Some alternatives to clear-cutting include: •shelterwood harvesting, in which mature trees are removed in a series of two or more cuts.•strip-cutting, in which all the trees in a narrow corridor are harvested. •selective cutting, in which only a small percentage of the mature trees are taken in each 10-or 20-year rotation.

Fire ManagementIn the 1930s, the U.S. Forest Service adopted a policy of aggressive fire control and Smokey Bear was adopted as the forest mascot.Attempts to suppress all fires may have been misguided. Many biological communities are fire-adapted and require periodic burning for regeneration. Eliminating fire from these forests has allowed woody debris to accumulate, greatly increasing the chances of a very big fire.

Ecosystem-based Management

Ecosystem-based management: “In ecosystem-based management, the associated human population and economic/ social systems are seen as integral parts of the ecosystem. Most importantly, ecosystem-based management is concerned with the processes of change within living systems and sustaining the goods and services that healthy ecosystems produce. Ecosystem-based management is therefore designed and executed as an adaptive, learning-based process that applies the principles of the scientific method to the processes of management.”United Nations Environment Programme(UNEP)

Payment for ecosystem services (PES)•PES is defined as:•“Maintaining the flow of a specified ecosystem service, such as clean water, biodiversity, habitat, or carbon sequestration, in exchange for something of economic value, [e.g., cash payments].” (Forest Trends, the KatoombaGroup, UNEP 2008)

PES

REDD•ReducingEmissionsfromDeforestationand forest Degradation•An effort to create a financial value for the carbon stored in [tropical] forests, offering incentives for developing countries to reduce emissions from forested lands and invest in low-carbon paths to sustainable development•REDD Programs can be found in:•Africa, e.g., Nigeria, Tanzania, Zambia•Latin America, e.g., Costa Rica, Ecuador, Bolivia and Colombia•Asia-Pacific, e.g., Viet Nam, the Philippines, Indonesia •Website: http://www.un-redd.org/Home/tabid/565/Default.aspx

REDD•Launched in 2008 as a collabora\on of the Food and Agriculture Organiza\on, UNDP and UNEP•Outcome of post-Kyoto mee\ngs, e.g., Bali, Copenhagen, Cancun and Warsaw•Reduce greenhouse gas emissions from deforestaOon and forest degradaOon in developing countries (contribute 20% of global GHG emissions)•Work to improve the livelihoods of forest-dependent communiOes•Address food producOon, protecOon of biodiversity and ecosystem services as well•Provide for the meaningful involvement of all forest stakeholders, including indigenous groups•Ensure gender equity•Assist developing countries in meeOng sustainable development goals and GHG emission targets•Note: REDD programs are administered by the home country•With funding from Denmark, the EU, Japan, Luxembourg, Norway and Spain

There is an Uneven Distribution of Water Resources

Dealing with Water ScarcityThe World Health Organization considers an average of 1000 m3 (264,000 gallons) per person per year to be a necessary amount of water for modern domestic, industrial, and agricultural uses.About a third of the world’s current population lives in countries where water supplies don’t meet everyone’s minimum essential water needs.

The Hydrologic (Water) Cycle Constantly Redistributes WaterWater cycles endlessly through the environment.This water evaporates from moist surfaces, falls as rain or snow, passes through living organisms, and returns to the ocean in a process known as the hydrologic cycle.Solar energy drives the hydrologic cycle by evaporating surface water, which becomes rain and snow.

In South America, shrinking glaciers are threatening agricultural production & city water supplies in the Andes.

Groundwater Supplies are Being DepletedGroundwater provides nearly 40% of the fresh water for agricultural and domestic use in the United States. Subsidence, or sinking of the ground surface, follows.Another consequence of aquifer depletion is saltwater intrusion.
