Water Pollution:  Pollution Includes Point Sources and Nonpoint Sources•Point sources discharge pollution from specific locations•Includes: drain pipes, ditches, or sewer outfalls such as factories, power plants, sewage treatment plants, underground coal mines, and oil wells.•Nonpoint sources have no specific location where they discharge into a particular body of water•includes: runoff from farm fields and feedlots, golf courses, lawns and gardens, construction sites, logging areas, roads, streets, and parking lots.

•About 3/4 of the water pollution in the U.S. comes from soil erosion, fallout of air pollutants, and surface runoff from urban areas, farm fields, and feedlots.•including sediment, fertilizers, and pesticides that flow from fields.•Most of these are nonpoint discharges.•Nonpoint sources are harder to control than point sources
Leading Causes of Surface Water Impairment

Biological Pollution Includes Pathogens and WasteThe most serious water pollutants in terms of human health worldwide are pathogenic(disease-causing) organisms.Among the most important waterborne diseases are typhoid, cholera, bacterial and amoebic dysentery, enteritis, polio, infectious hepatitis, and schistosomiasis.Water related diseases: 25 million deaths/ year; 2/3 of child mortality (0-5)If any coliform bacteria are present in a water sample, infectious pathogens are usually assumed to be present also.Organic impurities: manure and soil from agricultural land, waste matter from flora and fauna, excreta from humans
https://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/water-and-sanitation/

Nutrients and Cultural Eutrophication•Rivers and lakes that have clear water and low biological productivity are said to be oligotrophic (oligo= little;  trophic = nutrition).•Eutrophic (eu= trophic ; well-nourished) waters are rich in organisms and organic materials.•Human activities can greatly accelerate eutrophication  by using products with fertilizers (phosphates).•Human-caused eutrophication = cultural eutrophication
Eutrophic Lake

Copyright © The McGraw-Hill Companies, Inc. Permission required for reproduction or display.Eutrophic Lake
© William P. Cunningham
What Great lake is this?1.Addition of nutrients (N & P)2. Increase in algal growth(algae = phytoplankton, cyanobacteria)4. Algae dies off (reaches carrying capacity)5. Decomposition of algae uses up oxygen & creates hypoxic zones.
3. Some algae produce toxins, water is undrinkable.6. Hypoxia kills fish and other aquatic organisms

Eutrophication Can Also Occur in Marine EcosystemsPartially enclosed seas, such as the Black, Baltic, and Mediterranean Seas, as well as the Gulf of Mexico, tend to be in especially susceptible to eutrophication.Effluents from nearby large cities may be dumped untreated into the sea. Beach pollution, fish kills, and contaminated shellfish result. Extensive “dead zones” (areas with very low or no oxygen) often form where rivers dump nutrients into estuaries and shallow seas.
Death by Fertilizer –Hypoxia in the Gulf of Mexico

Dead Zones & Your Diet
https://theconversation.com/how-your-diet-contributes-to-nutrient-pollution-and-dead-zones-in-lakes-and-bays-118902

Inorganic Pollutants Include Metals, Salts, and AcidsSome toxic inorganic chemicals are naturally released into water from weathering of rocks but humans can accelerate this process by our actions. Among the chemicals of greatest concern are heavy metals, such as mercury, lead, tin, and cadmium.Released from mining activity, e.g., silver, gold & copper.Such heavy metals are highly persistent, they accumulate in food chains and effect humans.Mercury, released from incinerators and coal-burning power plants, is the most widespread toxic metal contaminant in North America.

Sediment Can Also Degrade WaterSedimentis a natural part of river systems.•Sediment = fine soil particulates + fine organic materialSediment can be a goodthing:•Fertilizing floodplains•Creating fertile deltas & estuaries•Building new shoreline, replacing eroded shorelineSediment can be a bad thing:•Human activities, chiefly farming and urbanization, have greatly increased sediment loads in rivers.•Sediments smother gravel beds in which insects take refuge and fish lay their eggs. •Sunlight is blocked, so that plants cannot carry out photosynthesis, and oxygen levels decline.
Copyright © The McGraw-Hill Companies, Inc. Permission required for reproduction or display.Sources of Groundwater Pollution

Groundwater is Especially Hard to Clean UpAbout ½ of the people in the United States, including 95% of those in rural areas, depend on underground aquifers for their drinking water. This vital resource is threatened in many areas by overuse and pollution and by a wide variety of industrial, agricultural, and domestic contaminants.The EPA estimates that 1.2 trillion gallons of contaminated water seep into the ground in the U.S.When deep underground aquifers are contaminated, it is possible, but expensive, to pump water out of aquifers, clean it, and then pump it back.Example:Dioxane Plume in SE Michigan (Scio & Washtenaw Counties)

How Do We Treat Municipal Waste?
•Under natural conditions, water purification occurs constantly in soils and water. The high population densities of cities, however, produce much more waste than natural systems can process.•Most developed countries require that cities and towns build municipal water treatment systems to purify the human and household waste. •Most rural households use septic systems, which allow solids to settle in a tank, where bacteria decompose them.https://annarborchronicle.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/WWspr2012_forweb.pdf

Municipal Treatment Has Three Levels of QualitySanitary engineers have developed ingenious and effective municipal wastewater treatment systems:•Primary Treatment physically separates large solids from the wastestream with screens and settling tanks.•Secondary Treatment uses aerobic bacteria to break down dissolved organic compounds.•Tertiary Treatment removes dissolved metals and nutrients, especially nitrates and phosphates.

Constructed Wetlands Can Be a Viable Option for Wastewater Treatment•Constructed wetlands are complexes of artificial marshes designed to filter and decompose waste.•Effluent from these operations can be used to irrigate crops or raise fish for human consumption if care is taken first to destroy pathogens. •Usually 20 to 30 days of exposure to sun, air, and aquatic plants is enough to make the water safe.

Bioremediation & Buffer Strips•Often, living organisms can clean contaminated water effectively and inexpensively. We call this bioremediation.•Some plants are very efficient at taking up heavy metals and organic contaminants. Bioremediation offers an inexpensive alternatives to conventional clean-up.•Riparian buffer strips:  forests, wetlands,  other forms of vegetation along stream banks or lake margins can effectively filter out sediment and remove pollutants beforethey reach a waterway. •Farmers and landowners often receive payments to set aside these buffer strips.10-43
https://savemaumee.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Riparian-Buffer-Initiative-Signs-2018-1024x575.png

Population EcologyStudy of the structure and dynamics of populations

Population GrowthOrganisms have an intrinsic rate of reproduction (r) that influences population size. Birth rates –death rates = r (intrinsic rate of reproduction)Many species have potential to produce almost unbelievable numbers of offspring. This is called the biotic potential—the unrestrained biological reproduction or an organism.

3-10Population Growth Without Limits is Exponential•Exponential (r) growth is population growth with no limits and has a distinctive shaped “J” growth curve.•This is represented by: dN/dt = rN•Where N = population size•t = time•d = change•When r remains constant over time, you get exponential growth•r is always a value between 0 and 1

Population Growth Without Limits is ExponentialA larger value of r means faster population growth•When r = 0Birth rate ? Death ratePopulation is in equilibrium (no change)•When r > 1Birth rate ? Death ratePopulation is increasing•When r < 1Birth rate ? Death ratePopulation is decreasing

Population Growth Without Limits is Exponential•What have you seen in the news lately that is an example of exponentialgrowth?•In reality, can the exponential growth of a population continue indefinitely?

Permission required for reproduction or display.Environmental Limits Lead to Logistic GrowthNot all biological populations cycle through exponential overshoot and catastrophic dieback. Internal and external factors can bring a species into equilibrium with their environmental resources. When resources are unlimited, they may grow exponentially, but this growth slows as the carrying capacity of the environment is approached. This population dynamic is called logistic growth because of its changes in growth rate over time.

Logistic Growth of a PopulationdN/dt = rN(K-N/K)N: # of organisms; K: carrying capacitydN/dt: Change in numbers over timerN: Exponential growth rate(K –N/K): Adjustment for resources (carrying capacity)•N<K: Growth rate is ______________•N>K: Growth rate is ______________•N = K: Growth rate is _______________09/22/103-21

Limits to Population SizePopulation growth rates are affected by external and internal factors:•Density-dependent factors are those affected by population size . For example, there is an increased risk that disease or parasites will spread, or that predators will be attracted to the area as a population increases. (e.g. Lynx & Hare)•Density-independent factorsare limits to population that are nonbiological and are the result of capricious acts of nature. A population is affected no matter what its size. (e.g., reindeer, saiga die-offs)•https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/31/science/lightning-strike-dead-reindeer.html•https://www.cbc.ca/radio/asithappens/as-it-happens-thursday-edition-1.4493061/why-220-000-saiga-antelope-died-suddenly-in-kazakhstan-in-2015-1.4493622

Species Respond to Limits Differently: R-and K-selected Speciesr-selected species: •r-selected: high intrinsic growth rate (high birth rate), often exhibit rapid growth-overshoot-collapse•Exponential growth pattern•Low trophic levels and niche generalistsK-selected species:•k-selected: low intrinsic growth rate (low birth rate), high offspring survival, tend toward equilibrium (density dependent; K)•Growth slows as they near K•Often slower maturing, fewer offspring•Examples?

Permission required for reproduction or display.The Competitive Exclusion PrincipleThecompetitive exclusion principle states that two species cannotoccupy the same ecological niche for long.•The species that is more efficient in using available resources will exclude the other.•The other species disappears or develops a new niche, exploiting resources differently, a process known as resource partitioning.•Partitioning can allow several species to utilize different parts of the same resource and coexist within a single habitat.

Permission required for reproduction or display.Resilience of Communities Seems Related to ComplexityComplexityrefers to the number of trophic levels in a community and to the number of species at each of those trophic levels.Resilience: ability of an ecosystem to recover from a disturbanceStability: ability of an ecosystem to resist change despite a disturbance (e.g. rainforest after a hard rain vs. coniferous forest after a forest fire)In most cases the more complexity a community possesses, the more resilient it is when disturbance strikes.

However, Some Communities Depend on Disturbance•Ecologically, a disturbance is any force that disrupts the established patterns of species diversity and abundance, community structure, or community properties.•Ecologists have found that disturbances like floods and forest fires actually benefit many species. •These are called disturbance-adapted species.Cottonwood: flood adaptedLodgepole pine: fire adapted
